attributes.Title: Intro African Amer English
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Linguistics
389
UMass Amherst
African American English (AAE) is a linguistic variety with set rules governing sentence structure, sound structure, word structure, and meaning. We will investigate five areas related to the structure and use of AAE in social contexts: speech events, components of the grammar, history, educational issues, and representation in the media and literature. Satisfies the Integrative Experience requirement for BA-Ling majors.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

The course is divided into four units: Models of Inquiry; the Impact of Science and Technology; Social Philosophy and Civic Engagement; and Art in the World. The course is supplemented with several plenary lectures by distinguished honors faculty speakers.
This course is open to Commonwealth Honors College students only.

attributes.Title: Lang. Processing & the Brain
attributes.Description:
Fall
2014
Linguistics
412
UMass Amherst
Introduction to psycholinguistics and neurolinguistics, with emphasis on techniques and results of recent theoretical and experimental work and the psychological underpinnings for the mental representation and processing of language. Primary focus on comprehension, and the biological basis of language, relation of linguistic capacity to brain structure and at most limited discussion of language production and language acquisition.  Satisfies the Integrative Experience requirement for BA-Ling majors.  Prerequisite: LINGUIST 201.
Pre Req: LINGUIST 201  Fulfills the Integrative Experience requirement
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: ST-Linguistics/Sign Language
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Linguistics
397S
UMass Amherst
In this course, we ask the question: how can sign languages inform our understanding of grammar? Sign languages are, on a par with spoken languages, instantiations of universal grammar, but they use the visual-gestural modality. Investigating their properties can thus reveal aspects of grammar which remain unobservable in the oral signal, due to articulatory constraints and other limitations relative to the linearity of speech. Furthermore, a better understanding of sign languages and of their commonalities with spoken languages also helps determine what in the linguistic signal (oral or visual) is contingent upon the physical limitations imposed by the medium, and what is an expression of the essential properties of language cognition. The course will cover a selection of phenomena (in phonology, syntax and semantics) that are important for understanding the structure of sign languages.
Pre Req: LINGUIST 201
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
70348

attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Linguistics
510
UMass Amherst
With lab. Introduction to the investigation of meaning from a linguistic, philosophical, and psychological point of view. How do words get their meanings, and how do we combine simple meanings to create complex ones? How can new meanings be created on the spot? What does context contribute to meaning? How are meanings connected to syntactic structure and intonation? Prerequisite: LINGUIST 201 and 401.

attributes.Title: Language and Cognition
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Linguistics
394BI
UMass Amherst
This course is a one-semester introduction to linguistics as a branch of cognitive science. Linguistics has been at the heart of cognitive science since the 1950's, and it's often said that language provides a privileged window on the inner workings of the mind. Throughout this course, we ask what exactly we learn about the mind by studying language. We will examine two classic arguments from linguistics that have been taken as informative about the structure of the mind: the argument for mental grammar, and the argument for innate knowledge. Specific topics include the nature of phonological and syntactic grammar, numerical cognition, reference and noun-phrase syntax, color systems, theory of mind, and event representations. Satisfies the Integrative Experience requirement for BA-Ling majors.
Pre Req: LINGUIST 201
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
68813

attributes.Title: The Dream of a Perfect Lang.
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Linguistics
392A
UMass Amherst
What makes a language perfect? How perfect are natural languages compared to their artificial counterparts? This seminar looks at a selection of artificial languages (e.g. 17th and 18th century concept calculi, Esperanto, Klingon), but also at opinions voiced by scholars ranging from Dante to Chomsky stressing that even natural languages might be close to perfect.  Prerequisite: LINGUIST 201.
Pre Req: LINGUIST 201
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

Prerequisite: LINGUIST 201.

attributes.Title: Intro to Linguistic Theory
attributes.Description:
Fall
2014
Linguistics
201H
UMass Amherst
How does the mind operate both creatively and rapidly? Is it like a computer? How does a rule operate upon itself? There are limits to possible grammars? Is the mind itself limited in the same way? How does a child acquire grammar? 
These questions lie in the background as we pursue a careful development of the rules of syntax for English. Students will learn the machinelike operation of how structures are built and altered. In addition we will look at the rules of how new lexical items are built by systematic rules of morphology. And we take a brief look at parallels in phonology and intonation.
We will investigate, step by step, how children build these structures and determine which grammar is theirs among all possible grammars. Students will be encouraged to do original searches on acquisition data available on the internet. This course aims for an in-depth study of one part of the mechanism of language and does not provide an overview or survey of the different parts of linguistics.  (Gen.Ed. R2)
Open to Commonwealth Honors College Students only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
79334

attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Linguistics
101

This course examines language as an instinct and as a social construct that dynamically shapes and is shaped by history, class, status, ethnicity, gender, and institutions like the media and the law. (Gen.Ed. U, SB)

attributes.Title: Intro to Language Acquisition
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Linguistics
411
UMass Amherst
How does a child choose one grammar from a million possible grammars? How are grammar and thought alike and not alike. Stresses the child's use of an inborn linguistic mechanism to produce creative sentences. Acquisition of syntax and semantics from the one-word stage through complex utterances. Linguistic principles as a window to unconscious principles of mind. Recent discoveries in the area of complex syntax. Students learn to search naturalistic data and do a small experiment.  Prerequisite:  LINGUIST 201.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
62612
Requisite: How does a child choose one grammar from a million possible grammars? How are grammar and thought alike and not alike. Stresses the child's use of an inborn linguistic mechanism to produce creative sentences. Acquisition of syntax and semantics from the one-word stage through complex utterances. Linguistic principles as a window to unconscious principles of mind. Recent discoveries in the area of complex syntax. Students learn to search naturalistic data and do a small experiment.  Prerequisite:  LINGUIST 201.

attributes.Title: Field Methods
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Linguistics
404
UMass Amherst
Provides hands-on experience in linguistic analysis. Students elicit language data from the speaker of an unfamiliar language, both  in class and individually. Under the guidance of the instructor, students analyze various aspects of the phonology and syntax of the language.
PreReq: Ling 401 & 402 or 414  This class fulfills the IE requirement
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Linguistics
611
UMass Amherst
Background psychological and biological assumptions made in linguistic theory and the abstract models they involve. Problems of learnability and parsability are primary topics. Structure and relevance of experimental approaches to these questions.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Speech Sounds and Structure
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Linguistics
402
UMass Amherst
Introduction to the field of phonology and the sound patterns of human language. Emphasizes the development of analytic skills through problem sets. Includes discussion of recent developments in phonological theory, particularly Optimality Theory.
Pre Req: LINGUIST 201
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
62624

attributes.Title: Intermediate Syntax
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Linguistics
503
UMass Amherst
This course investigates the common syntactic properties underlying human languages. This is done by comparing similar linguistic structures in a variety of related languages and teasing apart the phenomena that seem constant from the parts that seem to vary. This process also showcases how to construct and evaluate theories of syntactic phenomena. Prerequisite: Linguistics 401 or 401H.
Pre Req: LINGUIST 401 or 401H
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
62611
Requisite: This course investigates the common syntactic properties underlying human languages. This is done by comparing similar linguistic structures in a variety of related languages and teasing apart the phenomena that seem constant from the parts that seem to vary. This process also showcases how to construct and evaluate theories of syntactic phenomena. Prerequisite: Linguistics 401 or 401H.

attributes.Title: Syntactic Theory
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Linguistics
604
UMass Amherst
This is the second course in the graduate syntax sequence. Topics introduced in Ling 601 are examined in greater depth and students are introduced to more of the current literature. Topics typically covered include phrase structure, movement relations, anaphora, and the relationship between syntactic representation and semantic interpretation. Requirements include problem sets and a short paper.
Open to Graduate students only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
62586

attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Linguistics
720
UMass Amherst
A bridge between the introductory courses 610 and 620 and more advanced seminars. Content variable from year to year. Prerequisites: LINGUIST 610 and 620.
Pre Req: LINGUIST 610 or 620
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
32622
Requisite: A bridge between the introductory courses 610 and 620 and more advanced seminars. Content variable from year to year. Prerequisites: LINGUIST 610 and 620.

attributes.Title: Lang Acquisition&Human Nature
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Linguistics
190A
UMass Amherst
Language acquisition proceeds through sharp, clear steps that reflect on how our mind is organized. Should all of human nature, emotions, gestures, conscious and unconscious thought be built  on the same model?
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
41327
32651

attributes.Title: Intro To Syntax, Hons
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Linguistics
401H
UMass Amherst
Introduction to syntactic theory, with implications for universal grammatical theory in general.  Topics include theories of phrase structure, the form and functioning of transformations, grammatical relations, anaphora and control, cord order problems, universals of grammar, relations between grammatical theory and learnability, language acquisition.
Pre Req: LINGUIST 201
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
19758

attributes.Title: Formal Foundations Ling Theory
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Linguistics
609
UMass Amherst
Intensive introduction to statistical methods used in the analysis of linguistic and experimental data, as well as techniques used in stochastic models of language acquisition and processing. Topics covered will include contemporary use of statistical methods and models in linguistic research.
Permission is required for interchange registration during all registration periods.
62656

attributes.Title: Psycholinguistics: Ling. Form
attributes.Description:
Fall
2014
Linguistics
712
UMass Amherst
Introduction to psycholinguistics concentrating on the perception of linguistic form and the comprehension of discourse. Mental representation of grammar, psychological reality of linguistic models, empirically-motivated processing models. Prerequisite: LINGUIST 601.
Pre Req: LINGUIST 601
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
72463
Requisite: Introduction to psycholinguistics concentrating on the perception of linguistic form and the comprehension of discourse. Mental representation of grammar, psychological reality of linguistic models, empirically-motivated processing models. Prerequisite: LINGUIST 601.

attributes.Title: Seminar: Language Production
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Linguistics
393A
UMass Amherst
How do speakers use the grammar of their native language to produce sentences? How are complex thought/messages conveyed? This course will examine psycholinguistic theories of language production, highlighting questions such as: why are some speech errors common and other exceedingly rare? How are utterances prosodically encoded? How are words assessed and syntactically structured? What is the relation between language and thought? Prerequisites: LINGUIST 201.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
19253
Requisite: How do speakers use the grammar of their native language to produce sentences? How are complex thought/messages conveyed? This course will examine psycholinguistic theories of language production, highlighting questions such as: why are some speech errors common and other exceedingly rare? How are utterances prosodically encoded? How are words assessed and syntactically structured? What is the relation between language and thought? Prerequisites: LINGUIST 201.

attributes.Title: Phonological Theory
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Linguistics
606
UMass Amherst
Investigation of issues in current generative phonological theory. Construction of theoretical arguments using original evidence. Prerequisite: LINGUIST 603.
Open to Graduate students only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
62587
Requisite: Investigation of issues in current generative phonological theory. Construction of theoretical arguments using original evidence. Prerequisite: LINGUIST 603.

attributes.Title: Language Acquisition
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Linguistics
711
UMass Amherst
Theoretical foundations and methodology of the study of child language. Relationship between language acquisition, study of universal grammar, and theoretical psychology. Experimental term project customary. Prerequisite: LINGUIST 601.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
39693
39742
Requisite: Theoretical foundations and methodology of the study of child language. Relationship between language acquisition, study of universal grammar, and theoretical psychology. Experimental term project customary. Prerequisite: LINGUIST 601.

attributes.Title: Struct of a Non-Indo-Euro Lang
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Linguistics
748
UMass Amherst
Phonology and syntax of a language other than English. Emphasis on the application of current linguistic theory to   analytical problems presented by that language and the testing of current theoretical hypotheses by reference to        those problems. An informant generally used. Within each of these courses, languages vary from year to year; any of them may be repeated for credit. Prerequisites: LINGUIST 601, 603.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
19283
Requisite: Phonology and syntax of a language other than English. Emphasis on the application of current linguistic theory to   analytical problems presented by that language and the testing of current theoretical hypotheses by reference to        those problems. An informant generally used. Within each of these courses, languages vary from year to year; any of them may be repeated for credit. Prerequisites: LINGUIST 601, 603.
